Line 39: Line 39:
UNetbootin's distinguishing features are its support for a great variety of Linux distributions, its portability, its ability to load custom [[Kernel (computer science)|kernel]], [[initrd|initial ramdisk]] and [[disk image]] (including [[ISO image]]) files, and its support for both Windows and Linux.<ref name="UNetbootin Forum Thread">{{cite web | url=http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=427540 | title=Install Ubuntu Without a CD | publisher=Ubuntu | author=Geza Kovacs (tuxcantfly) |
UNetbootin's distinguishing features are its support for a great variety of Linux distributions, its portability, its ability to load custom [[Kernel (computer science)|kernel]], [[initrd|initial ramdisk]] and [[disk image]] (including [[ISO image]]) files, and its support for both Windows and Linux.<ref name="UNetbootin Forum Thread">{{cite web | url=http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=427540 | title=Install Ubuntu Without a CD | publisher=Ubuntu | author=Geza Kovacs (tuxcantfly) |
â
accessdate=2007-10-10}}</ref> Unlike [[Wubi_(Ubuntu)|Wubi]], and similar to the [[Win32-loader (Debian)|Win32-Loader]], when installing to hard disk, UNetbootin installs to a [[Disk partitioning|partition]], not a [[disk image]], thus creating a [[dual-boot]] setup between Linux and Windows.
+
accessdate=2007-10-10}}</ref> Unlike [[Wubi (installer)|Wubi]], and similar to the [[Win32-loader (Debian)|Win32-Loader]], when installing to hard disk, UNetbootin installs to a [[Disk partitioning|partition]], not a [[disk image]], thus creating a [[dual-boot]] setup between Linux and Windows.
